pitt.search.semanticvectors.vectors

Class RealVector

  • java.lang.Object
    • pitt.search.semanticvectors.vectors.RealVector
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Vector

    public class RealVector
extends java.lang.Object
implements Vector
    Real number implementation of Vector. Supports both sparse and dense formats. Some methods automatically transform from sparse to dense format. Callers should be made aware through documentation of when this is done, since there may be performance consequences.
    Author:
    Dominic Widdows

      • generateRandomVector

        public RealVector generateRandomVector(int dimension,
                              int seedLength,
                              java.util.Random random)
        Generates a basic sparse vector with mainly zeros and some 1 and -1 entries (seedLength/2 of each) each vector is an array of length seedLength containing 1+ the index of a non-zero value, signed according to whether this is a + or -1.
        e.g. +20 indicates a +1 in position 19, +1 would indicate a +1 in position 0. -20 indicates a -1 in position 19, -1 would indicate a -1 in position 0.
        The extra offset of +1 is because position 0 would be unsigned, and would therefore be wasted. Consequently we've chosen to make the code slightly more complicated to make the implementation slightly more space efficient.
        Specified by:
        generateRandomVector in interface Vector
        Parameters:
        dimension - number of dimension of vector returned
        seedLength - number of non-zero entries, usually a combination of +/-1 entries as determined by implementation
        random - random seed for generation
        Returns:
        Sparse representation of basic ternary vector.

      • measureOverlap

        public double measureOverlap(Vector other)
        Description copied from interface: Vector
        Returns a canonical overlap measure (usually between 0 and 1) between this and other.
        Specified by:

      • superpose

        public void superpose(Vector other,
             double weight,
             int[] permutation)
        Description copied from interface: Vector
        Superposes other vector onto this one with given weight, usually by vector addition. Coordinates of other vector may be permuted and reweighted in the process. Permuted coordinates supports encoding of order information, as begun by Sahlgren, Holst and Kanerva 2008.
        Specified by:
        superpose in interface Vector
        Parameters:
        other - vector to be added
        weight - multiple of other vector added (TODO widdows support complex weights)
        permutation - represents the permutation to be applied while adding, so that the ith coordinate of other is added to the coordinate given by the ith entry in this list. Can be NULL in which case no permutation is applied.

      • bind

        public void bind(Vector other,
        int direction)
        Description copied from interface: Vector
        Binds the other vector into this one. Does not necessarily guarantee that this.bind(other, 1) is equal to other.bind(this, -1).
        Specified by:
        bind in interface Vector
        direction - if direction > 0, binding is on the right, otherwise it is on the left

      • normalize

        public void normalize()
        Description copied from interface: Vector
        Transforms vector to a normalized representation. A normalized representation should satisfy the property that measureOverlap with itself is equal to 1.0, to within precision tolerances.
        Specified by:

      • sparseToDense

        protected void sparseToDense()
        Automatically translate sparse format (listing of offsets) into full float vector. The sparse vector is in condensed (signed index + 1) representation, and is converted to a full float vector by adding -1 or +1 to the location (index - 1) according to the sign of the index. (The -1 and +1 are necessary because there is no signed version of 0, so we'd have no way of telling that that zeroth position in the array should be plus or minus 1.)

      • getCoordinates

        public float[] getCoordinates()
        Available to support access to coordinates for legacy operations. Try not to use in new code!
